text.p: Following are the main stories in Croatian newspapers on Wednesday.
- A working group comprising United Nations and Croatian government representatives says an agency for selling abandoned Serb property may be established by the end of the month.
- Foreign Minister Mate Granic to head the Croatian delegation setting off for the Washington talks on May 15.

- The Croatian Social Liberal Party (HSLS) has no rational reason to reject a coalition with the ruling Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ) party in the city of Zagreb, says deputy HDZ president Ivic Pasalicin in an interview.
- Is the United States to invest some $10 million in the Croatian energy grid and its roads? U.S. companies that are mentioned as possible investors: Bechtel, Enserch and Enron.
- Senior members of HSLS Drazen Budisa and Ivo Skrabalo describe as sensible their party's candidature of Vlado Gotovac for president in the upcoming June 15 presidential elections.
- Average interest rates have been cut by 26 percent since the beginning of 1996 due to banks competing with each other.
- We want personal autonomy in order to be able to deal with economic, cultural, educational and other problems in Eastern Slavonia, says Serb member of parliament in an interview.
- Mobile phones are blamed for an increased number of traffic accidents. In 1996 alone, some 140 crashes were put down to the use of carphones.
- Zagreb was the hottest city in Europe on Tuesday with temperatures soaring to 28.9 degrees Celsius.
- EU is to give guarantees to the European Investment Bank for projects in 57 countries, but Croatia is not among them.
- Croatian delegation to start talks at the World Trade Organisation headquarters on bilateral concessions, prior to its membership of the organisation.
- The jeans producer Levi's and its Croatian business partner Varteks to continue their partnership but Varteks will have to meet the ecology standards required by Levi's.

- The only definite candidate running in the presidential elections at this point is Franjo Tudjman, while possible other candidates are: Zdravko Tomac of the Social Democratic Party, Vlado Gotovac of the HSLS and Anto Dapic of the Croatian Party of Rights.
- The shares on the Zagreb Bourse have been slumping over the past week, but experts say this is just a temporary slip.
- Some 140 foreign reporters to cover the Dalmatia Cup 97 sailing competition that is to commence on May 17 in Biograd and end on May 24 in Makarska. -- Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
